info.game_comments: 2005 Ultimate Tournament of Champions Round 1, game 18.

(1, 1).clue: The fleet-footed Atalanta once lost a race to Hippomenes when she stopped to pick up these golden fruits

(2, 1).clue: This boxer with an 'earing problem tops the list of ESPN's most outrageous sports characters

(4, 1).clue: A Lerner & Lowe song lyric goes, "Thank heaven for" these people, "they grow up in the most delightful way"

(5, 1).clue: The first First Lady to be born in Texas

(6, 1).clue: If you've lost weight, Mom might say you're nothing but these 2 anatomical items

(1, 2).clue: This Roman goddess of wisdom is said to have leaped forth from the brain of Jupiter, fully mature & in armor

(2, 2).clue: He retired from the NHL for the final time in 1980, at age 52

(3, 2).clue: "Green Gables" girl of Prince Edward Island

(4, 2).clue: The Indian game moksha-patamu (heaven & hell) gave us this Milton Bradley game that has its ups & downs

(5, 2).clue: The first First Lady to be elected to public office

(6, 2).clue: The ingredients of this basic salad dressing might be the olive & balsamic types, respectively

(1, 3).clue: Hera punished this nymph by saying that she shall have the last word but no power to speak first

(2, 3).clue: This team owner bought his team in 1973 for a mere $10 million, & it's won 7 World Series since

(3, 3).clue: Once part of Alcoa, this Canadian company with a 5-letter name is a giant in world aluminum manufacturing

(4, 3).clue: The John Jakes novel "Heaven and Hell" takes place directly following this war

(5, 3).clue: The first First Lady to be older than her husband

(6, 3).clue: If Bo Peep seeks her sheep on mountains & in valleys, she's literally searching here

(1, 4).clue: Hamadryads were nymphs who lived in these; when they died, so did the hamadryads

(2, 4).clue: Michael "The Albatross" Gross won gold medals in this sport using an arm span far exceeding his height

(3, 4).clue: Quebec's Shickshock Mountains are part of this system that runs to Alabama

(4, 4).clue: In Genesis 1, God gave the name Heaven to this, from the Latin for "support"

(5, 4).clue: The first First Lady to serve for 3 consecutive presidential terms

(6, 4).clue: In 2002 Scotland's Inverness Prison reenacted its 1st inmate's arrival 100 years earlier, complete with this apparatus

(1, 5).clue: Heracles' seventh labor was to bring Eurystheus this savage Cretan animal

(2, 5).clue: This ice skater (& boxer) helped lift a night of Winter Olympics coverage to one of the highest rated TV shows ever

(3, 5).clue: Centered in Nova Scotia, it was the name applied by France to its Atlantic coastal possessions in North America

(4, 5).clue: The final movie in Oliver Stone's Vietnam trilogy, this film starred Hiep Thi Le & Tommy Lee Jones

(5, 5).clue: First name of the first First Lady to live in the White House

(6, 5).clue: "The Federalist" No. 51 argues for the Constitution's "Partitian of Power", now called this system

(1, 1).clue: This element known to the ancients is liquid at room temperature

(2, 1).clue: "Mamma Mia" takes place on one of this country's islands; the plot concerns a big fat wedding

(3, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew milks a cow at Old World, Wisconsin.) Jersey cows, vital to the dairy industry, produce 40 pounds of milk a day; if a gallon weighs 8 pounds, that's this many gallons--I think I'm gonna need a bigger bucket

(4, 1).clue: This type of peach is so named because its flesh does not cling to the pit

(5, 1).clue: Theodore Dreiser's classic about the actress who played Princess Leia

(6, 1).clue: The vehicle in which the deceased travels to the cemetery

(1, 2).clue: The 2 radioactive elements named for planets that follow uranium on the periodic table

(2, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from the Gershwin Theatre in New York.) The cast of "Wicked" sings about spending one short day in this place, a major metropolis in the land of Oz

(3, 2).clue: If oats cost 40 cents a peck & you spend $1.20 on them every day, you have this type of habit

(4, 2).clue: It's a corn tortilla rolled around a filling in a flute-like shape, so its name is Spanish for "flute"

(5, 2).clue: Jack London's masterpiece about a sled dog who delivers a famous brand of Kentucky bourbon
(5, 2).correct response: The Call of the Wild Turkey

(6, 2).clue: A round solid geometric figure, or a field of knowledge

(1, 3).clue: 2 of the ores for this yellowish-green gas are rock salt & horn silver

(2, 3).clue: Shubert Alley is the setting for both the opening & closing scenes of this smash hit that debuted in 2001

(3, 3).clue: If you make half of your 16 pigs run to get their slop, you'll hear the sound of this many feet on the ground

(4, 3).clue: A Louisiana French word for "twisted" gave us the name of this gumbo powder

(5, 3).clue: Amy Tan's happy-go-lucky book about a luncheon item made with chicken, bacon & several slices of toast

(6, 3).clue: A Mexican poncho without the hole

(1, 4).clue: This element, symbol Ti, was first called menachite after the cornish town of its discovery, Manaccan

(2, 4).clue: (Hi, I'm Kate Monster.) And in "Avenue Q", atop this famous skyscraper, I sing "I Wish I Could Go Back To College"--don't forget to say "What is"!

(3, 4).clue: If it takes 50 pounds of seed to grow an acre of wheat, a ton of seed will get you this many acres

(4, 4).clue: It's often described as bow tie pasta, but its name comes from the Italian for "butterflies"

(5, 4).clue: Hemingway's book about an elderly guy trying to catch an echinoderm that looks like a giant pickle
(5, 4).correct response: The Old Man and the Sea Cucumber

(1, 5).clue: All elements except this one have neutrons in the nucleus

(2, 5).clue: Act I, scene 1 of this Sondheim musical introduces us to "Nippon. The floating kingdom"

(3, 5).clue: Ga. & N.C., each producing $3 million of grapes a year, combine to total this percentage of New York's $50 million

(4, 5).clue: The name of this pleasantly bitter herb is derived from the Latin fenum Graecum, which means "Greek hay"

(5, 5).clue: Depressing Dickens tome about the legislative body that met in colonial Virginia in 1619

(0, 0).clue: Dutch for either "devil's whirlpool" or "spite the devil", Spuyten Duyvil Creek forms part of its northern border
